/COMMIT_MSG.message:
can we ever complete the migration successfully at this point. if we are doing a live migration and qemu exits on the source or dest then it is going to fail. we should probably try and revert instead if it not a post copy migration. If it is post then we proably should mark the migration as failed.

in a post copy migration if we have already got to the post copy stage then if either qemu exits we cannot recover as the instnace is executing on the dest node at that point paging ram locally and remotely form the source node.

in the non post copy case or if we have not switch to post copy mode then we should be able to revert and continue executing on the source node provided the source vm is not the one that was killed. 

if the source vm is the the one that is killed we can only ever complete sucessfully if we are doing a pre copy migration and we have already swapped to executing on the remote node. in all other cases if the source node is killed the we cant complete succesfully as the contents of ram form the source node will be lost.

From what Alexandre has commented on Feb 4, it is possible to complete the migration successfully at this point. He said that VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID is briefly a valid state during a successful live migration. The state is seen briefly before the virt domain is undefined and the migration is completed.

If the domain stays in the VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID state "too long" and never gets to undefining the virt domain, the live migration has failed. And this patch is returning VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_FAILED if it receives VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID the configured number of times, and that will trigger the recovery/rollback routine for live migration.

So it seems like this will do the right thing or at the very least would be a big improvement over what we have today.

I'm not sure if this should be "Specifically" but it doesn't make much of a difference - I would just remove this so you have "Zero means retries are disabled."

I think this should contain a bit more info explaining why you would want to retry on VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID. Something to do with how VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID is returned (briefly) during a normal successful live migration. But if it is returned repeatedly and the virt domain does not become undefined, it represents a failure in live migration and thus server cleanup routines should *not* be done, else they result in data loss.

nova/virt/libvirt/guest.py.message: I'm not sure we want to add this retry logic, it's not directly related to the bug (wrong assumption of migration complete). And I would think, if you get INVALID once, there's a fair chance you will get it again during your retries.

Hm, based on the previous code, I'm not sure we can assume that VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID means that the live migration is not complete. That is, we may not be able to distinguish between migration complete (domain disappeared) or migration failed (qemu process died).

I think we need some investigation into VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID and if we might need to examine the error message to be able to differentiate between fail and complete.

This is where the original code came from -- libvirt raises INVALID when migration of a persistent guest completes. So I think we need to dig a little more to hopefully find a difference in the error message that we can use to tell shutoff vs process inaccessible.

OK, I found the code where this is returned [1][2] (I'm looking at v1.3.1 because that's our MIN_LIBVIRT_VERSION in nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py

So, when libvirt returns this error, the error message will be:

 virReportError(VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID, "%s",
 _("domain is not running"));

I'm thinking we could check if ex.get_error_message() contains 'domain is not running', we use the old behavior and treat the migration as complete. Else, we treat the migration as failed and return JOB_FAILED. According to the FAQ [3], stopping the daemon process should not shutdown VMs (please test this to be sure, if you can).

What do you think?

[1] https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/v1.3.1/src/qemu/qemu_driver.c#L13058
[2] https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/v1.3.1/src/qemu/qemu_driver.c#L12999-L13023
[3] https://wiki.libvirt.org/page/FAQ#Will_restarting_the_libvirt_daemon_stop_my_virtual_machines.3F

Sigh, upon re-reading the bug description, apparently libvirt will say 'domain is not running' even in the case where the qemu process has been killed via OOM killer. So, what I suggested isn't going to work.

I was concerned that if we change VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID from complete to failed, we'll report FAILED for migrations that actually completed.

I think that for live migration, it might be OK because IIRC, live migration uses only a transient domain. And looking at the libvirt driver code, it doesn't look like we use this job info functionality for cold migration at all.

Can you tell me a bit more about how the retry helps in your bug scenario? If the qemu-kvm process has been killed, are you finding that it is automatically restarted but not killed again? How is the retry helping you?

Thanks for the explanation. That helps me understand your approach in this patch.

So, the retry is for the case where there is a short window of time the guest is SHUTOFF before it disappears from the source host. You could get a problem if the short window is just a bit too long and would have completed if you had waited more. And live migration would be considered failed. That is why you have the config option.

According to the code comment on L958, when a persistent guest completes live migration, it shuts off but does _not_ go away. That is why we can't get NO_DOMAIN for the persistent guest. It will just remain SHUTOFF when it completes.

So, in that case, your approach is saying, we should use the jobStats() as the source of truth for completed migration. Persistent domain can SHUTOFF for the configured number of retries before we expect to receive JOB_COMPLETED.

That does seem like a reasonable way to handle this issue. I'll ask Kashyap to take a look at his earliest convenience.

While in the end of live migration, looks like the domain on the source host will be shut down and gone. Normally, we treating VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID as success is fine because there surely is a short time SHUTOFF. But in my bug scenario, the qemu-kvm process is killed by OOM killer, and you can see the domain is SHUTOFF by ``virsh list --all``, it's STILL on the source host, not undefined or gone, but SHUTOFF, in such case, doing self._domain.jobStats() gets error VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID. The qemu-kvm will not be restarted automatically but keep status SHUTOFF until someone finally notices. In such case, you cannot see VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID as success, right?

By pretending that the migration job is still in progress while hitting VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID and retry to get job stats, we will eventually distinguish whether the migration task is successful:
* migration succeeds, domain is gone, `self._domain.jobStats()` gets VIR_ERR_NO_DOMAIN or just normal completion job stats.
* migration fails, domain is SHUTOFF and not gone, `self._domain.jobStats()` gets VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID

In a nut shell, we treat only the VIR_ERR_NO_DOMAIN exception as VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_COMPELTED. Of course, we won't mess with normal completion here.

I'm still not sure this is the correct thing to do, considering that persistent guests will return this same error when they shut down, and should be considered "job completed." 

What I'm wondering is if we ever have persistent guests involved in live migration. I'd like Kashyap to take a look at this review and give his comment.

Even if it is for a short time, if it is possible for a persistent guest to live migrate, if it shuts down as part of the migration, this code will consider it to be "job failed" when it should be "job completed."

If it is not possible for a persistent guest to live migrate, then this would be OK.

Thanks so much for the reply and the comments, Melanie. IMHO, shutoff status only keeps for a short time, the domain is eventually gone from source host and starts on the destination host. Hope someone can find the answer from libvirt or qemu codes. Really looks forwards to Kashyap's comments. :)

specs/ocata/nodegroups.rst.message: should this be 'Heterogeneous node clusters'?
I was thinking at least 2 node groups are required (one for master nodegroup and one for non-master node group). Is there any reason for zero?

To follow up on this, I think that drivers should be able to enforce what NGs can exist in a cluster themselves rather than putting that logic in the engine. For example, the difference between master and minion in the newest versions of Kubernetes can be as little as a node label, which is freely changeable from the Kubernetes API. I want the driver to be able to ignore the concept of a master NG altogether. The magnum engine can ask drivers to validate whether a NG (or set of NGs) can be added. The other drivers should be free to implement the logic of "if there are currently no master NGs and there are no master NGs that are in the list to be added, don't allow it".

With NodeGroups, a cluster can exist without nodegroups.  It is unlikely that any stacks will be created until there is at least a master and non-master, but from an resource point of view it can still exist. It is just a cluster shell waiting for nodegroups to be added.

A Cluster with no NodeGroups can include the networking bits. This can be helpful if the user wishes to completely change the node types of a cluster but wants to keep the cluster IP the same. I think the point of having a cluster with no NodeGroups can be explained here.
'minion' seems to be more of kubernetes related term. How about some generic term, like worker node?
This was being discussed in the big spec review as well. We need to come to an agreement on what term to use. I've seen non-master and worker.  Any other suggestions from the team?
potentially each node group would be a stack, so why not move stack_id to node group? what is the use of stack_id here?
The cluster itself will likely be a stack for share resources.  This might change with the implementation. If it does then we can remove it from Cluster and have it only in the nodegroups
If I understand correctly, nodegroup table will contain both master and non-master node addresses... is my understanding correct?
Correct, a nodegroup will have a master flag that will specify if that nodegroup is a master or not. So node_address will contain the address in the master nodegroup.
I think that CLI examples are smaller details than this spec should be covering, and possibly even going over individual operations too.

Included them to give a more concrete reference to how the nodegroups might work when implemented.  The examples are heavy on the CLI information though so the CLI spec might be a better location for them
Ditto, in my opinion all of this belongs in the CLI spec.
Would lifecycle operation only apply to cluster and not nodegroup?  In other words, the operation would be executed on all nodegroups in the cluster.

Some lifecycle operations could apply to nodegroups individually as well.  Originally I had an example in this of the restart operations that was being proposed for restarting a cluster. I included it as an example of an operation that we might just want to run on a single nodegroup instead of the entire cluster.

If a lifecycle operation is requested on a cluster it would be performed on all nodegroups(if needed). If requested on a nodegroup, it would be limited to that nodegroup.  It is possible that some lifecycle operations will not need to know about the nodegroups so they will be cluster only. Others like restart I can see as being available for both cluster and nodegroup operations.

Support may be available at the COE level to achieve similar goals, for instance Kubernetes federation:
https://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/federation/
I like the change from minion to worker. Calling it non-master instead doesn't get the point across in my opinion.

This implies that we will support V1 and V2 simultaneously.
In turn this means that the implementation for the V1 API will be modified to work on the V2 data model.  
For clarity, it would be helpful to spell out the scenarios:
-V1 API only with V1 data model
-Migrate V1 data model to V2 data model and support V1 + V2 API
-V2 API only with V2 data model

Correct.  Second options is the current implementation plan. Data model will be migrated first and V1 API implementation will be updated to support the V2 data model. The V2 API will then be added.  I can add that detail to this section.

Worth adding a case for 'http://storage.test.com/swift' ?

We should also have variants with a trailing slash; I'm not sure we want 'http://storage.test.com/' mapping to 'http://storage.test.com//info' :-/

I'm a little nervous about testing _map_url directly without testing that we actually call it as part of Connection.get_capabilities... I can apply a diff like

diff --git a/swiftclient/client.py b/swiftclient/client.py
index 960fada..9cad040 100644
--- a/swiftclient/client.py
+++ b/swiftclient/client.py
@@ -1949,7 +1949,8 @@ class Connection(object):
         return urlunparse((scheme, netloc, path, params, query, fragment))
 
     def get_capabilities(self, url=None):
-        parsed = urlparse(self._map_url(url))
+        parsed = urlparse(urljoin(url or self.url or self.get_auth()[0], '/info'))
         if not self.http_conn:
             self.http_conn = self.http_connection(url)
         return get_capabilities((parsed, self.http_conn[1]))


(essentially backing out your fix while keeping _map_url around) and tests still pass.

Fortunately, we *do* still have pretty good coverage -- if I cause a NameError somewhere in Connection.get_capabilities, like five tests still pop.

controllerconfig/controllerconfig/script.message: Why wasn't this required for the other certs we are copying? Is it OK to do this every time the controller reboots?

> Thanks Andy - please add a short comment here explaining this.
 > Also - you didn't answer my question about whether this is safe to
 > do this on every controller reboot.

Sorry I missed the second part of the question. Yes it is safe to re-run "update-ca-trust extract" multiple time (this is the case on reboot).

Thanks Andy - please add a short comment here explaining this.
Also - you didn't answer my question about whether this is safe to do this on every controller reboot.

> Why wasn't this required for the other certs we are copying? Is it
 > OK to do this every time the controller reboots?

Here we are adding a CA certificate to system trusted CA cert list, and update-ca-trust is the Linux utility to do that. Basically when a new CA cert is put in /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors, it doesn't get into the trusted list, utill this command is run.

The other certs are not CA certs that need to be added into system trusted CA cert list.
Is there a return code to be checked here?

> Is there a return code to be checked here?

The return code is not reliable. For example, even we put an invalid certificate in /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors/, the command still return 0. There could be more complicated checking after the command in the future. Good news is that this command never fail if the provided certificate is valid, and the process to generate this cert is rather reliable, if it's generated, it's valid. Otherwise the cert file won't be created.
Recommend adding a check for rc, or at least a comment that the rc is currently not reliable

I think this is a better way of handling exception and logging.
The caller which catches and handles the exception reraise from here will log the exception. With the raise (without parameter e) is reraise the exception, which includes the entire callstack info from the original exception being raised. LOG.exception(e) here duplicates exception logging, while missing helpful info, in this case name and namespace of the certification that failed the operation.
Use LOG.exception when logging exceptions and do not pass the exception as a parameter.
